importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the AWS outage event, which disrupted global internet services and highlighted systemic vulnerabilities in cloud infrastructure.
The last major AWS outage prior to the 2025 incident, illustrating the relative rarity of such events and the growing concern over their increasing impact.
The date of the largest-ever IT outage due to a CrowdStrike software glitch, used for context on how widespread and costly internet outages can be.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe during which the AWS DNS outage lasted and was resolved, indicating the duration and recovery timeline of the incident.

keyTakeAways: The internet's reliance on a small number of cloud providers like AWS makes it vulnerable to outages, even if brief.
The root cause of the outage was a failure in the Domain Name System (DNS) that prevented access to AWS-hosted databases such as DynamoDB.
Many online services—banking, social media, shopping, and airline booking—were disrupted due to the inability to locate critical data.
The outage underscores the fragility of the internet’s infrastructure and the lack of redundancy in cloud computing services.
Experts suggest that companies have 'put all their eggs in one basket' by relying heavily on a single cloud provider.
The incident is believed to be a technical fault, not a cyberattack, according to cybersecurity experts.

namedEntities.name: Amazon Web Services (AWS)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A cloud computing platform that hosts critical online services such as banking, social media, and e-commerce.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: AWS was directly affected by the outage, and its failure disrupted a vast array of internet services globally.

namedEntities.name: Domain Name System (DNS)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A system that translates human-readable web addresses into IP addresses.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A DNS failure caused a breakdown in communication between users and AWS-hosted data, making services inaccessible.

namedEntities.name: DynamoDB
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A database service hosted by AWS that stores customer and application data.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Customers could not access data stored in DynamoDB due to the DNS failure, causing temporary service outages.

namedEntities.name: EC2
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A virtual server service used by companies to build online applications.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The EC2 service was also affected by the DNS outage, impacting businesses relying on virtual servers.

namedEntities.name: CrowdStrike
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A software company that provided cloud-based IT security and system management solutions.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A 2024 CrowdStrike software glitch caused a global IT outage, used as a precedent to show the potential scale and cost of similar failures.

namedEntities.name: AT&T
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: AT&T experienced network outages in 2024, including an 11-hour meltdown, illustrating broader systemic vulnerabilities in digital infrastructure.

namedEntities.name: Rob Jardin
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Chief digital officer at NymVPN, a cybersecurity firm.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He provided expert analysis suggesting the outage was a technical fault, not a cyberattack, and highlighted internet decentralization concerns.

namedEntities.name: Mike Chapple
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Cybersecurity expert and IT professor at the University of Notre Dame.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He explained the disproportionate attention given to AWS outages due to their widespread impact and the lack of redundancy in cloud systems.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Amazon Web Services (AWS) experienced a significant global outage on October 20, 2025, during which its Domain Name System (DNS) failed to communicate with critical databases such as DynamoDB, preventing users from accessing a wide range of online services including banking, social media, shopping, and airline booking platforms. Although the outage lasted only a few hours and was resolved by 6:35 AM ET, it highlighted the fragility of the internet’s digital backbone, as so much of the world’s online ecosystem depends on a limited number of cloud providers. Experts, including Rob Jardin and Mike Chapple, noted that the incident appears to be a technical fault rather than a cyberattack and emphasize the lack of redundancy and decentralization in modern internet infrastructure. This event echoes previous large-scale outages, such as the 2024 CrowdStrike software failure and AT&T’s 2024 network meltdown, underscoring a growing global concern about the risks of over-concentration in cloud computing services.
title: The internet just had another global outage. Why does this keep happening?
